definition:
Let $X$ be a vector space and $S \subset X$. Then $x \in S$ is called an
[*internal point*]{} of $S$ if and only if the intersection of each line
in $X$ through $x$ and $S$ contains a small interval around $x$.

That is $x$ is an internal point of $S$ if whenever $y \in X$ there
exists an $\epsilon > 0$ such that $x + ty \in S$ for all
$t < \epsilon$.

If $X$ is a topological vector space and $x$ is in the interior of $S$,
then it is an internal point, but the converse is not true in general.
However if $S \subset {\mathbb{R}}^n$ is a convex set then all internal
points are interior points and vice versa.

[9]{} H. L. Royden. **. Prentice-Hall, Englewood Cliffs, New Jersey,
1988
